questions.question: The Pap smear of a healthy 30-year-old lady is given below. Identify the microorganism seen.
All of the following are risk factors for PID except_
questions.explanation: Pregnancy is not a risk factor for PID. Instead, it plays a protective role in this condition.739The risk factors for developing PID are:•Unprotected sexual intercourse.Having multiple sex partners• Previous history of PID• IUD insertion• Early age of sexual intercourse (<18years)The protective factors for PID are:• Pregnancy•Using barrier contraception like condoms, diaphragms• Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)• Menopause

questions.question: 731A 24-year-old woman is diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease. Which of the followingis not included in this condition?
questions.explanation: Cervicitis is not included in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).Pelvic inflammatory disease is a spectrum of infection and inflammation of the upper genitaltract, typically causing:• Endometritis•Salpingitis•• Oophoritis• PeritonitisThe minimum criteria for diagnosis of PID are:Pain in the lower abdomen + any one of the following:• Uterine tenderness• Cervical motion tenderness•• Adnexal tendernessCervicitis and vaginitis are lower genital tract infections.

questions.question: What is the most common symptom seen in acute PID?

options.D: Pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen

questions.explanation: The most common symptom of acute PID is bilateral lower abdominal pain.The pain is severe in acute stages and it may or may not be accompanied by a high temperature (>38.3 degrees C). It may be followed by vomiting.Some patients with PID can present with pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. This isseen in Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome which is a form of perihepatitis.740If PID occurs due to sexually transmitted organisms, dysuria and vaginal discharge may be seen.

questions.question: A young woman with fever and lower abdominal pain is diagnosed to have PID. Which is themost common cause for this condition?
questions.explanation: Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of PID.PID is an infection of the upper genital tract. It is generally transmitted sexually as an ascendinginfection along with sperms. It is usually a polymicrobial infection,Organisms causing PID include:Sexually transmitted:Chlamydia (most common)• Gonococcus• Mycoplasma• TrichomonasPyogenic Aerobes:• Staphylococci• Streptococci⚫ E ColiAnaerobes:• Bacteroides fragilis• Peptostreptococcus• ClostridiumActinomyces (most common in IUD users)Other:•Mycobacterium tuberculosisNote: Genital tuberculosis is the only PID that does not spread sexually. It has a hematogenousspread. Thus, it is the most common PID in virgin girls.

questions.question: A 42-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with abdominal pain and fever forthe last 48 hours. She has been using a Cu T 380A for contraception for the past 8 years. Onexamination, cervical motion tenderness was present. What is the most likely organism tohave caused her condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of PID in an IUCD user. The most commonorganism causing this condition is Actinomyces. It has been reported in 7% of IUCD users if thedevice is worn for more than 2 years.This emphasizes the need for strict asepsis during insertion of the device and the need for strictfollow up of women wearing these devices.Organisms causing PID are:741Sexually transmitted:•Chlamydia (most common)• Gonococcus•Mycoplasma•TrichomonasPyogenic Aerobes:• Staphylococci.Streptococci⚫ E Coli•Anaerobes:• Bacteroides fragilis•• Peptostreptococcus• Clostridium.Actinomyces (most common in IUD users)Other:• Mycobacterium tuberculosis

questions.question: What is the mechanism of the spread of gonococci to the tubes in pelvic inflammatorydisease?
questions.explanation: The mechanism of the spread of gonococci to the tubes in pelvic inflammatory disease is mucosal.Gonococci ascend to the tubes mainly through mucosal continuity. This is facilitated by sexuallytransmitted vectors such as sperms and Trichomonas.The mucous membranes of the fallopian tubes are affected first. They become edematous and areinfiltrated with leukocytes and plasma cells. Another route of spread is through the reflux ofmucosal blood.Option A: Hematogenous spread is seen in genital tuberculosis.Option B: Lymphatics are involved in the spread of secondary organisms and in PID followingpost-abortal and puerperal infection.Option C: Parametrium facilitates the spread of Mycoplasma. The gut flora can directly spread totubes.

questions.question: Which infection causes more damage to the mucosa and the wall of the tube leading tofibrosis and tubal blockage?
questions.explanation: Among the given options, chlamydial infection causes the most amount of damage to the mucosaand the wall of the fallopian tubes leading to fibrosis and tubal blockage.742Chlamydial infection can remain asymptomatic in the endo-cervix. Hence, the infection goesunnoticed and untreated. Thus, it can lead to more damage and complications.Gonococcal infection is more symptomatic than chlamydial infection. Hence, it is diagnosed earlyand causes less damage to the tubes than chlamydial infection.Mycoplasma and Mobiluncus generally cause lower genital tract infections like cervicitis andvaginitis.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis of acute PID?
questions.explanation: Pelvic endometriosis is not a differential diagnosis of acute PID. It is a differential diagnosis ofchronic PID.Differential diagnosis of acute PID:••Acute appendicitisSeptic abortion•Cholecystitis•Twisted ovarian cyst•Ectopic pregnancy• Diverticulitis•Ruptured endometriotic cystDifferential diagnosis of chronic PID:• Uterine fibroids• Pelvic endometriosis•Ovarian tumourTubercular tubo-ovarian mass

questions.question: A 26-year-old female with endometritis did not complete the course of antibiotics she wasprescribed. Following this, her infection failed to resolve and she developed a tubo-ovarianmass. How can this mass manifest?
questions.explanation: The given scenario of development of a chronic tubo-ovarian mass following acute PID pointstowards a diagnosis of chronic PID. A chronic tubo-ovarian mass can manifest as a tubo-ovariancyst, hydrosalpinx or even a chronic pyosalpinx.Failure to complete treatment of acute PID or drug resistance can lead to the development ofchronic PID. This can lead to the development of chronic tubo-ovarian masses which maymanifest as:• Hydrosalpinx• Chronic pyosalpinx• Chronic interstitial salpingitis743• Tubo-ovarian cyst• Tuberculous formA twisted ovarian cyst and a ruptured endometriotic cyst are differential diagnoses of acute PID.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition seen in the imagegiven below?

options.C: Flattening of tubal plicae is seen on histology
options.D: Its ampullary region is filled with clear fluid

questions.explanation: The above image depicts a hydrosalpinx. Its wall is not opaque but translucent.If a pyosalpinx responds to antibiotics, the pus present inside becomes sterile within 6 weeks ofthe initial attack. However, the damage to the tube remains as chronic pyosalpinx orhydrosalpinx. A hydrosalpinx represents the end result of previous acute salpingitis and is oftenbilateral.The tube becomes retort shaped due to the enormous dilatation of the ampullary region that isfilled with clear fluid.Histological examination shows a flattening of the tubal plicae and exfoliation of the liningepithelium.

questions.question: A patient with fever and abdominal pain presented to the emergency. On examination, younote mucopurulent vaginal discharge and cervical motion tenderness. You suspect she hasPID. Which of these is not included in the criteria to diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation: Bilateral abdominal pain is not included in the criteria to diagnose PID. Bilateral abdominal painis a clinical symptom of PID.Lower abdominal tenderness is included in the criteria to diagnose PID.CDC criteria for the diagnosis of PID:Definitive criteria:• Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy• Imaging study (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (tubo-ovarian abscess)•• Laparoscopic evidence of PIDMinimum criteria:•Cervical motion tenderness• Uterine tenderness• Adnexal tendernessAdditional criteria:• Oral temperature >38.3 OC•Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge, cervical friability• Raised ESR or CRP•Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia744

questions.question: Which of the following is not a definitive criterion used to diagnose PID?
questions.explanation: A temperature of more than 38.3°C is an additional criterion and not a definitive criterion for thediagnosis of PID.CDC 2006 criteria for the diagnosis of PID:Definitive criteria:••Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsyImaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (Tubo-ovarian abscess)• Laparoscopic evidence of PIDMinimum criteria:• Lower abdominal tenderness• Adnexal tenderness• Cervical motion tendernessAdditional criteria:• Oral temperature>38.3CMucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability• Raised ESR or CRP• Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia

questions.question: A 24-year-old woman presented with bilateral abdominal pain for 3 days and a temperatureof 102°F. She also had a mucopurulent vaginal discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and anegative urine pregnancy test. Which is the gold standard investigation to confirm her likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is likely to be acute PID. Laparoscopy is the gold standard to confirmacute PID.Laparoscopy is not done routinely as it is an invasive procedure. It is reserved for only caseswhere the differential diagnosis is salpingitis, appendicitis, ectopic pregnancy or a case of anon-responding pelvic mass.The diagnosis of PID is mostly clinical. If diagnosis is unclear, the investigation of choice for PIDis USG and culdocentesis.CDC 2006 criteria for the diagnosis of PID:Definitive criteria:•⚫ Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy•Imaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (tubo-ovarian abscess)• Laparoscopic evidence of PIDMinimum criteria:745• Lower abdominal tenderness• Adnexal tenderness• Cervical motion tendernessAdditional criteria:• Oral temperature>38.3CMucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability• Raised ESR or CRP• Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia

questions.question: The laparoscopy report of a woman with pelvic inflammatory disease states she hasGainesville stage III PID. Which of the following presentations could have been seen in her?
questions.explanation: Gainesville stage III includes two forms of PID - acute salpingitis with superimposed tubalocclusion or tubo-ovarian complex.Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage asfollows:StageConditionStage IAcute salpingitis without peri-tonitis no adhesionsStage IAcute salpingitis with peritonIitis - purulent dischargeStage IAcute salpingitis with superiIImposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complexRuptured tubo-ovarian absceStage IVSSStageVTubercular salpingitis

questions.question: In a patient with PID, laparoscopy shows the following appearance. What is true about thesyndrome this patient likely has?735
questions.explanation: The image shows the laparoscopic finding of violin string adhesions that are characteristicof Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. It is a form of perihepatitis that occurs in the setting of PID.It is characterized by right upper quadrant pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred tothe right shoulder. It rarely occurs in women with acute PID. The pathological mechanism is asfollows:Gonococcal / Chlamydial infection → transperitoneal/vascular spread → inflammation of the livercapsule and peritoneal surfaces → adhesions and fibrosis in the perihepatic region →Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome746Cholecystitis and ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess are the differential diagnoses of Fitz-Hugh-Curtissyndrome. Violin string adhesions would not be seen in these conditions.

questions.question: Identify the wrong statement with respect to silent PID.

options.D: Mycobacterium can be grown from menstrual blood

questions.explanation: Dysmenorrhea rarely occurs in PID. Pain is uncommon and is a result of subacute PID.Silent PID is thought to follow multiple or continuous low-grade infections in asymptomaticwomen. It is not a clinical diagnosis. Rather, it is an ultimate diagnosis given to women withtubal-factor infertility who lack a history of upper genital tract infection.On laparoscopy or laparotomy, these women may have evidence of prior tubal infection such asadhesions, but for the most part, the fallopian tubes are grossly normal. They can have ectopicpregnancies due to tubal dysmotility. Silent PID can occur following infection with M.tuberculosis.

questions.question: A patient is admitted to the gynaecology ward for pelvic inflammatory disease. Which of thefollowing is a part of this patient's treatment regimen?

options.A: Administration of cefotetan 2 g IV 12 hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV BD
options.B: Removal of IUD irrespective of antibiotic response
options.C: Administration of a single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg IM
options.D: Administration of 10 doses of Placentrex 2ml IM daily or on alternate days736

questions.explanation: Administration of cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hoursforms the crux of the treatment regimen for PID. This is followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg+/-metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days in all hospitalized patients having PID.Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients:•⚫ Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hours is given followed byoral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days• Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route.•Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia.Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current RCOG guidelines):.• A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/-metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days•• A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks.IUD is not removed in a woman who responds to antibiotics. It is removed only in case of a failedantibiotic response. Barrier contraceptives and OCPs are recommended only in womenunresponsive to antibiotics.The use of Placentrex (aqueous extract of the placenta) is outdated and is not recommendedcurrently.

questions.question: A 30-year-old female presents to the OPD with fever, lower abdominal pain and purulentvaginal discharge. On examination, her vitals are stable and per vaginal examination revealslower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness. What is the best treatment option for her?

options.A: Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg with oral doxycycline and metronidazole for 14 days
options.B: Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 7 days
options.C: Oral doxycycline 100 mg BD with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 7 days
options.D: Oral ofloxacin 200 mg BD with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of fever and lower abdominal pain associated with lower abdominaland cervical motion tenderness is suggestive of PID. The best treatment option for this patient is747outpatient treatment with a single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD+/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days.Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current RCOG guidelines):• A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mgBD x 14 days• A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks.Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients:•Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hours is given followed byoral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days• Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route.•Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia.

questions.question: Which of the following would be an indication for surgery in a 30-year-old woman diagnosedwith PID?
questions.explanation: Intestinal obstruction would be an indication for surgery in a patient diagnosed with PID.Criteria for surgery in PID include:• Drainage of pelvic abscess by colpotomy.• Dilatation and evacuation of septic products of conception or for haemorrhage in the postabortalperiod.• Acute spreading peritonitis resistant to a full course of chemotherapy. Presence ofpyoperitoneum mandates laparotomy.•••• Intestinal obstructionSuspected intestinal injury as diagnosed in criminal abortion.Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscessA tubo-ovarian abscess of 2 cm is not an indication for surgery. Minimally invasive surgery isdone in a tubo-ovarian abscess measuring more than 10 cm, that fails to respond to antibiotics in48-72 hours.Peritonitis and sepsis are not an indication for surgery. They should be managed medically first. Ifthey do not respond to antibiotic treatment then surgical management should be done.

questions.question: Which among the following is an indication for minimally invasive surgery for tubo-ovarianabscess?

options.A: The size of the abscess is more than 5 cm
options.B: The size of the abscess is more than 2cm
options.C: The abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 48 - 72 h
options.D: The abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 24 - 36 h

questions.explanation: If the abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 48-72 h, minimally invasive surgery is indicated.Criteria for minimally invasive surgery in PID:• The size of the abscess is more than 10 cm• The abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 48-72 hours748• The abscess ruptures•PyoperitoneumMinimal invasive surgery includes laparoscopic drainage of the tubo ovarian abscess or posteriorcolpotomy.

questions.question: A 55-year-old multiparous woman who presented with chronic lower abdominal pain hasbeen diagnosed with chronic PID. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation: The treatment of choice for an old multiparous woman with chronic PID is abdominalhysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.A radical hysterectomy involves the removal of the whole uterus, tissue from the sides of theuterus, the cervix, and the upper part of the vagina. It is generally done only in cancer patients.A supracervical hysterectomy involves the removal of only the body of the uterus and is not donein chronic PID. It is done for the treatment of endometriosis, uterine fibroids, and uterineprolapse.

questions.question: Who has described the prognostic evaluation for PID?
questions.explanation: Boer-Meisel has described the prognostic evaluation for PID. It depends upon the following:• Extent of adhesions•• Nature of adhesions such as flimsy or dense.• Size of hydrosalpinx• Macroscopic condition of hydrosalpinx.• The thickness of the tubal wall.Boer-Meisel system is specifically used for predicting pregnancy outcomes in patients treated forPID.Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage.Westrom has reported that women with one previous attack of PID have a predisposition toanother attack.Stages of PIDStage IAcute salpingitis without peritonitis no adhesionsStage IAcute salpingitis with peritonIitis- purulent dischargeStage IIIAcute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex749Stages of PIDStage IRuptured tubo-ovarian absceVSSStageVTuberculous salpingitis

questions.question: Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to pyometra. This refers to the collection of pus inthe uterine cavity.The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands,skene glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. Unilateral pain and swelling over the labia maybe caused by the inflammation of the Bartholin glands.Depending on the extent of tissue involved, PID can be classified into five stages• Stage I - Acute salpingitis without peritonitis - No adhesions••Stage II - Acute salpingitis with peritonitis - purulent dischargeStage III - Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo ovarian complex• Stage IV - Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess•Stage V - Tubercular salpingitisLong-standing pelvic inflammation may also lead to:⚫ Dyspareunia• Infertility•Ectopic pregnancy• Formation of adhesions like hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, tubo-ovarian abscess• Chronic pelvic painNote: Chronic pelvic inflammation leads to dense adhesions between the uterus and theappendages. Thus, it becomes difficult to define the uterus from the pelvic masses. They form ahard mass which is called the frozen pelvis.The most common cause of the spread of PID: Ascending infection along with spermsThe only PID that does not spread with the sexual route is genital TB. It has a hematogenousspread.The most common PID in virgin females is genital TB.Investigation of choice in PID: Abdominal USGThe surest sign of salpingitis is pus extruding from the fimbrial end of the tube.750
